comments.text:
Your tax penalty (shared responsibility fee) for not having insurance is 
paid on your federal income taxes at the end of the year. If your taxable 
income is below 133% of the federal poverty level you are exempt from this 
tax.

2014 = $95 per person per year or 1% of your Income
2015 = $325 per person per year or 2% of your Income
2016 = $695 per person per year or 2.5% of your Income
2017 = Tax Penalty will increase by the rate of inflation going forward, or 
2.5% of your Income

• If you’re uninsured for just part of the year, 1/12 of the yearly penalty 
applies to each month you’re uninsured.

• The penalty is based on modified adjusted gross income and is paid on 
your federal income taxes.

• The total penalty for the taxable year cannot exceed the national average 
of the annual premiums of a bronze-level health insurance plan offered 
through the health insurance marketplaces.

• The maximum penalty per family is capped at no more than 300% of the 
minimum penalty (e.g. $695 x 300% = $2,085).

• Children under 18 are assessed at 50% of the minimum penalty.

• The penalty is pro-rated for the number of months you are without health 
insurance, though there is no penalty for a single gap in coverage of less 
than 3 months in a year. 

• Health insurance plans will provide proof of coverage for their customers 
so as long as you have health insurance you don't have to worry about the 
details.

(via Obamacarefacts: A dot com)

comments.text:
+Corelius Vexius Interesting, my grandfather had colon cancer and he was 
cured. In fact, he died of something unrelated to cancer: advanced age. And 
indeed, cancer treatment has significantly reduced the chances of one dying 
from cancer. Your assertion is just not up to par. 

But lets put aside the cancer argument for the sake that it is a bad 
generalization. Instead, lets turn to what the conservative purpose of the 
Affordable Care Act is: reducing the rate of healthcare cost increases to 
the rate of inflation. Why? Because healthcare cost, historically, have 
risen faster than the rate of inflation, which in turn, caused premium 
increases for all Americans thus making in affordable for many. 

To archive this purpose, two main factors had to be addressed. (1) People 
with out insurance were going to the E.R and not paying for services 
rendered. (2) The pool of people in the healthcare market needed to be 
increased to, collectively, reduced cost (more people paying premiums to 
control cross and subsidize coverage for others.) This is why the mandate 
was created, to address these factors. And so far in has succeeded. 7.1 
million people have singed up for plans on the exchanges because they don't 
want the fine for not having insurance. According to the CBO, the rate of 
health care cost, for the first time, have risen at a rate historical of 
inflation. The CBO also states that the cost of premiums on the exchanges 
are stable, meaning that the consumers will not see a sharp price increase 
in the near future from insurance providers. If one were to look at the 
Massachusetts plan upon which the ACA was based, then you will find that 
the rate of enrollment and the rate of healthcare cost in the state 
correlate to this same effect. 

Now I grant that the ACA is not the crown jewel of health care. Some people 
will pay more for insurance, some people will pay less for insurance. This 
is because (1) Insurance has to cover more than it has had to do 
historically (another factor in controlling cost. (2) More people must be 
covered by insurance (even people who were denied insurance in the past for 
preexisting conditions. (3) Our model is not a government based model (the 
ACA is private insurance and thus ultimately it is up to them to set the 
price of their plans, not the government.) 

With this said, one would be hard pressed to not to conclude that, so far, 
the ACA, like the plan it was modeled after, is on track to achieving its 
intended purpose: A stable health care market..

comments.text:
+TheRetiredtrucker 

As the law's initial enrollment period closes, at least 9.5 million 
previously uninsured people have gained coverage. Some have done so through 
marketplaces created by the law, some through other private insurance and 
others through Medicaid, which has expanded under the law in about half the 
states.
The tally draws from a review of state and federal enrollment reports, 
surveys and interviews with insurance executives and government officials 
nationwide.

• At least 6 million people have signed up for health coverage on the new 
marketplaces, about one-third of whom were previously uninsured.
• A February survey by consulting firm McKinsey & Co. found 27% of new 
enrollees were previously uninsured, but newer survey data from the 
nonprofit Rand Corp. and reports from marketplace officials in several 
states suggest that share increased in March.
• At least 4.5 million previously uninsured adults have signed up for state 
Medicaid programs, according to Rand's unpublished survey data, which were 
shared with The Times. That tracks with estimates from Avalere Health, a 
consulting firm that is closely following the law's implementation.
• An additional 3 million young adults have gained coverage in recent years 
through a provision of the law that enables dependent children to remain on 
their parents' health plans until they turn 26, according to national 
health insurance surveys from the federal Centers for Disease Control and 
Prevention.
• About 9 million people have bought health plans directly from insurers, 
instead of using the marketplaces, Rand found. The vast majority of these 
people were previously insured.
• Fewer than a million people who had health plans in 2013 are now 
uninsured because their plans were canceled for not meeting new standards 
set by the law, the Rand survey indicates.

comments.author: Tyler Nearing

comments.text:
+TheRetiredtrucker Youtube sensors my links.

But why don't you just look it up. A 1 year old can type in say, 
"Affordable Care Act Statistics" into Google search and find the numbers on 
how many signed up for Medicaid, how many gained insurance, and how many 
people lost insurance.

Ignorance is never a valid defense to committing a crime.  

But, you want to know how many people paid, yet you are frustrated that no 
data is available on how many people paid aka "the deadbeat question". Well 
this is mainly because the market is based on demand and not payment; 
supply and demand. Indeed the argument itself is premature as many people 
have not even received their first premium bill, or have a payment due for 
another 6 or so weeks. So it is just going to take some time to get a clear 
picture on the "deadbeat question" you seek to answer.

Now I can tell you that the rates on the exchanges are based on this CBO 
projections supplied to private insurance companies: How people would want 
plans on the exchange, this is the equation they sought to predict, but 
included in this prediction is the assumption that failure and/or late 
payments would occur because, of course and as you rightfully assert, this 
would effect the stability of the exchanges. With this in mind, the CBO 
states today as of 4/2/2014, that, with all their assumptions, the 
enrollment figures for the ACA would have to hover around 7 million in the 
first year for rates to be stable for the first year. And they give us 
projections for next year and so on. Included is this number is a safety 
net, a assumption that their will be some "deadbeats" out of this 7 
million. So even if there is some percentage of "deadbeats" in the 
exchanges, as long as 7 million or so have selected plans, then one will 
not see a sharp increase in prices this year. thus for now, no death 
spiral. Also note that built into the ACA are several provision that would 
slow or prevent several this perceived death spirals and other threats to 
the ACA sustainability. Also note that the states and countries who have 
implemented similar legislation have healthy health care exchanges.

So the "deadbeat question" is ether over exaggerated, or not really 
relevant. It is not a silver bullet that will kill the ACA.
comments.author: Mike Jones

comments.text:
You've made it quite clear that if anyone gives you numbers you don't like 
you'll just say they aren't the "actual numbers" and point us to the blaze 
or some such. But since you asked here is a LA Times article on the matter 
of how many more people are covered now than before the ACA went into 
effect:

http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-obamacare-uninsured-national-20140331,0,5472960.story#axzz2xlQL813s

Don't like the LA Times? Fine check any other major newspaper they will say 
the same thing since the data is collected from the insurance companies 
themselves and the state-run healthcare exchanges.

Your question regarding how many have paid for it is irrelevant and treats 
medicaid as if it's something people aren't paying for despite anyone with 
a job paying into it. Same goes for subsidies. To act as though people 
using taxpayer provided programs aren't paying for them through their own 
taxes is ridiculous. If I ever have to go on it I sure as hell won't feel 
like I'm getting a hand-out after years of contributing to it through my 
state and federal taxes and likely continuing to contribute during and 
(hopefully) after needing it. Therefore I will not indulge your desire 
dismiss the number of people going on it or getting subsidies you'll just 
have to do a simple googling, oh the horror. How would you have fared 
finding information before the personal computer and world wide web I 
wonder...

comments.text:
drp, no they aren't. Yes, they cover more things, but my insurance when 
from $140 with a $2,000/person deductible to over $400 with this change. 
The only insurance plan I can now afford (monthly) is $140 but with a 
$6,000/person/year deductible. I think the changes to insurance are 100% 
positive in regards to covering pregnancy, pre-existing conditions and etc, 
but there has also been negative effects. I had to drop my insurance and 
now I have until April 20th to find something I can afford. A $2,000 
deductible would be seriously pushing it if anything major did happen. A 
$6,000+ deductible might as well be 6 million.
comments.author: Sar Ly

comments.text:
Your argument makes no sense whatsoever. Prescription charges maybe slight 
higher but insurance premiums are lower than they were under the 
republicans and the cost of spending a few extra hundred dollars for buying 
drugs is nothing in comparison to what the 40 million uninsured Americans 
had to pay out of their own pocket prior to Affordable Care Act. I know you 
want to take ACA care down a few notches but the majority of Americans are 
now very content with the changes, btw. If they weren't I would expect to 
see them protesting on mass

comments.text:
+2bRealist: "The days of $1,000 hammers is behind us.. hello $1,000,000,000 
websites... ouch O_o" 
Actually, yes, but it's not just websites.  The thing about corruption and 
crony capitalism is that it is inefficient.  When you bend, break, or 
otherwise rig the rules so that you profit more, there will simply be less 
money for the actual work. 
You saw this in Russia with the Sochi Olypmics that were the most expensive 
Olympics in history at $51 Billion.  Regardless of the details, Sochi was 
hardly the best organized Olympics ever.  That is the effect of 
crony-capitalism: your incompetent friends get these opportunities to make 
money. 
This is one of the major mechanisms that makes crony-capitalism inherently 
unsustainable.  And its only going to get worse...

meh, the website problems are just the usual manifestations of 
crony-capitalism.  These days the government uses contractors to do most of 
the work, and even when they allow bidding on a potential contract (as 
opposed to a no-bid contract which they just give to someone without much 
vetting), they typically use the same contracting firms over and over 
again.  It's not an excuse, but it is also not surprising.  Though I am 
surprised that it eventually cleared up, at least until today.
